𒊩 SAL 𒊩𒎌 šal-meš salves save 𓋴 𓈖 𓃀 𓏜 salambus seelig (wegen leg) saalık sağlıq salam

𒐼𒇴𒋫 sa3-lam-ta salam salvat slavat "slave" follower attendant

Although there is some phonetic and semantic overlap, the words slave and servant need to be treated separately, because officials are often attributed as servants to gods/society.

Since kings treated their people as slaves, and neighboring nations treated their enemies as slaves, the words for slaves, underlings, foreigners and many ethnicities are often related.
Since everyone is affected, one should not dismiss such connections due to political correctness ( or bad linguistics), even though words involved often have negative connotations.

Often these words are also related to sex workers, man and women, boys and girls

Dutch दास dā́sa dáasa
Related to Proto-Indo-Iranian *dásyuš- “enemy, foreigner, foreign people, foreign land”, from Proto-Indo-European *des- “enemy, foreigner”.

See also Persian ده, Old Avestan 𐬛𐬀𐬒𐬌𐬌𐬎 (dax́iiu, “country”, Younger Avestan 𐬛𐬀𐬣𐬵𐬎 (daŋ́hu). Ancient Greek δοῦλος (doûlos, “slave” perhaps belongs in this group as well.[1] Related to दस्यु (dasyu, “barbarian
